batchMetadata.description: Key differences between IFRS and US GAAP across major accounting topics

questions.question: Which inventory costing method is permitted under US GAAP but prohibited under IFRS?

options.B: Weighted average
options.C: LIFO
options.D: Specific identification

questions.explanation: LIFO (Last-In, First-Out) is permitted under US GAAP but explicitly prohibited under IAS 2. IFRS allows FIFO, weighted average, and specific identification. This is a significant difference that affects companies operating internationally or considering IFRS adoption.
questions.tip: Major GAAP/IFRS difference: LIFO is US GAAP only. IFRS prohibits LIFO.

questions.question: Under IFRS, if inventory previously written down to net realizable value subsequently increases in value, what is the accounting treatment?

options.A: No reversal permitted; carry at written-down amount
options.B: Reversal permitted up to original cost
options.C: Reversal permitted to current market value
options.D: Reversal only upon sale of the inventory

questions.explanation: Under IAS 2, if circumstances that caused the write-down no longer exist, the write-down is reversed, but only up to the original cost. US GAAP prohibits reversal of inventory write-downs. This is a key difference in inventory accounting between the frameworks.
questions.tip: Inventory write-down reversal: IFRS allows (up to cost). US GAAP prohibits any reversal.

questions.question: Which measurement model for property, plant and equipment is available under IFRS but not under US GAAP?

options.B: Revaluation model
options.C: Fair value through profit or loss
options.D: Impairment model

questions.explanation: IFRS allows a policy choice between cost model and revaluation model for PPE (IAS 16). Under the revaluation model, assets are carried at fair value with changes going to revaluation surplus (equity). US GAAP only permits the cost model for PPE, requiring historical cost less depreciation and impairment.
questions.tip: PPE measurement: IFRS allows cost OR revaluation model. US GAAP only allows cost model.

questions.question: How does IFRS treatment of significant components of PPE differ from typical US GAAP practice?

options.B: IFRS requires component depreciation for significant parts with different useful lives
options.C: US GAAP requires component depreciation; IFRS does not
options.D: Both have identical requirements for component depreciation

questions.explanation: IAS 16 requires that significant components with different useful lives or depreciation patterns be depreciated separately (component depreciation). While US GAAP permits component depreciation, it's not required and is less commonly practiced. This can result in different depreciation patterns.
questions.tip: Component depreciation: Required under IFRS for significant parts. Permitted but not required under US GAAP.

questions.question: A company impaired equipment by $100,000 two years ago. Conditions have changed and the asset's value has recovered. What is the IFRS treatment?

options.B: Reversal permitted and recognized in profit or loss, limited to revised carrying amount without impairment
options.C: Reversal must be recognized in OCI
options.D: Reversal only if asset is sold

questions.explanation: Under IAS 36, impairment losses on assets other than goodwill can be reversed if there's been a change in estimates used to determine recoverable amount. The reversal cannot exceed the carrying amount that would have existed (net of depreciation) if no impairment had been recognized. US GAAP prohibits reversal of impairment losses.
questions.tip: Impairment reversal: IFRS allows (except goodwill), limited to original carrying amount net of depreciation. US GAAP prohibits all reversals.

questions.question: How does the IFRS impairment model for long-lived assets differ from US GAAP?

options.A: IFRS uses a two-step test; US GAAP uses one-step
options.B: IFRS uses one-step (recoverable amount); US GAAP uses two-step (recoverability then fair value)
options.C: Both use identical impairment approaches
options.D: IFRS only tests goodwill for impairment

questions.explanation: IFRS uses a one-step approach: compare carrying amount to recoverable amount (higher of fair value less costs to sell and value in use). US GAAP uses two steps: (1) recoverability test comparing carrying amount to undiscounted cash flows, (2) if impaired, measure loss using fair value. IFRS may recognize impairment earlier.
questions.tip: Impairment tests: IFRS one-step (recoverable amount). US GAAP two-step (recoverability trigger, then fair value). IFRS often triggers impairment sooner.

questions.question: Under IFRS, when are development costs capitalized?

options.A: Never; all R&D must be expensed
options.B: When six specific criteria are met (technical feasibility, intent, ability, etc.)
options.C: Only for software development
options.D: Whenever management believes the project will be successful

questions.explanation: Under IAS 38, development costs must be capitalized when all six criteria are met: (1) technical feasibility, (2) intention to complete, (3) ability to use or sell, (4) probable future economic benefits, (5) availability of resources, and (6) ability to measure costs reliably. US GAAP generally expenses all R&D except certain software costs.
questions.tip: Development costs: IFRS capitalizes if 6 criteria met. US GAAP expenses (except software). Research always expensed under both.

questions.question: Under IFRS, can an acquired trademark with indefinite life be measured using the revaluation model?

options.A: Yes, if there is an active market for that type of asset
options.B: Yes, for all intangible assets
options.C: No, intangibles can only use cost model
options.D: Yes, but only for the first 5 years after acquisition

questions.explanation: IAS 38 permits the revaluation model for intangible assets only if fair value can be determined by reference to an active market. This is rarely available for most intangibles like trademarks. US GAAP does not permit revaluation of any intangible assets. Both require cost model when no active market exists.
questions.tip: Intangible revaluation: IFRS allows only if active market exists (rare). US GAAP prohibits revaluation model for intangibles.

questions.conceptTested: Fair value model for investment property
questions.question: How does IFRS treatment of investment property differ from US GAAP?

options.A: Only IFRS recognizes investment property separately
options.B: IFRS allows fair value model with gains/losses in income; US GAAP uses cost model
options.C: US GAAP uses fair value; IFRS uses cost
options.D: Treatment is identical under both frameworks

questions.explanation: Under IAS 40, investment property can be measured using either cost model or fair value model. Under fair value model, changes in fair value go to profit or loss. US GAAP does not have a separate standard for investment property and applies the cost model (depreciation/impairment) used for PPE.
questions.tip: Investment property: IFRS allows fair value with P&L impact OR cost. US GAAP: cost model only (treated as PPE).

questions.question: In a sale-leaseback qualifying as a sale under IFRS 16, how is the gain on the sale portion treated?

options.B: Gain deferred and amortized over lease term
options.C: Gain limited to the proportion of rights transferred to buyer-lessor
options.D: No gain recognized until end of leaseback

questions.explanation: Under IFRS 16, if a sale-leaseback qualifies as a sale, the seller-lessee only recognizes gain to the extent of the rights transferred to the buyer-lessor. The portion retained through the leaseback is measured relative to the original asset's carrying amount. This is proportional gain recognition. ASC 842 treatment is similar.
questions.tip: Sale-leaseback gain: Only recognize gain on rights transferred, not on portion retained through leaseback. Similar under both frameworks now.

questions.question: Following adoption of IFRS 15 and ASC 606, what is the relationship between IFRS and US GAAP revenue recognition?

options.B: Substantially converged with same 5-step model
options.C: IFRS recognizes revenue earlier than US GAAP
options.D: US GAAP has no specific revenue standard

questions.explanation: IFRS 15 and ASC 606 are substantially converged standards resulting from a joint FASB/IASB project. Both use the same 5-step model: (1) identify contracts, (2) identify performance obligations, (3) determine transaction price, (4) allocate to obligations, (5) recognize when obligations satisfied. Minor differences exist in specific application guidance.
questions.tip: Revenue recognition: IFRS 15 and ASC 606 are converged (same 5-step model). Minor differences in detailed guidance only.

questions.question: Under IAS 37, a provision is recognized when an outflow is 'probable.' How does the IFRS interpretation of 'probable' compare to US GAAP?

options.B: IFRS threshold is lower - 'more likely than not' (>50%) vs US GAAP 'likely' (~70-80%)
options.C: IFRS threshold is higher than US GAAP
options.D: Both require virtual certainty

questions.explanation: Under IFRS, 'probable' means 'more likely than not' (greater than 50% probability). Under US GAAP, 'probable' is interpreted as 'likely to occur,' which is generally considered a higher threshold (approximately 70-80%). This can result in earlier provision recognition under IFRS.
questions.tip: 'Probable' differs: IFRS = >50%. US GAAP = ~70-80%. IFRS recognizes contingent liabilities earlier.

questions.question: When measuring a provision involving a large population of items, what does IAS 37 require?

options.A: Use the minimum amount in the range
options.B: Use the maximum amount in the range
options.C: Use expected value (probability-weighted average)
options.D: Use the most likely amount only

questions.explanation: Under IAS 37, when a provision involves a large population of items, it's measured at the expected value (probability-weighted average). For a single obligation, the most likely outcome may be appropriate, but expected value is used when measuring obligations with statistical populations. US GAAP also uses expected value for certain measurements.
questions.tip: Provision measurement: Large population = expected value. Single obligation = most likely amount (IFRS), or low end of range if equally likely (US GAAP).

questions.question: Under IFRS 9, financial assets are classified based on:

options.B: Business model for managing assets AND contractual cash flow characteristics
options.C: Maturity date and credit rating
options.D: Historical cost or market value

questions.explanation: IFRS 9 classifies financial assets using two tests: (1) business model test (hold to collect, hold to collect and sell, or other), and (2) SPPI test (solely payments of principal and interest). This determines measurement at amortized cost, FVOCI, or FVPL. US GAAP classifications (trading, AFS, HTM) are based on different criteria.
questions.tip: IFRS 9 classification: Business model + SPPI test. Result: Amortized cost, FVOCI, or FVPL. Different framework than US GAAP's intent-based model.

questions.question: How does IFRS 9's expected credit loss model differ from US GAAP's CECL model?

options.A: IFRS uses lifetime losses immediately; US GAAP uses staged approach
options.B: IFRS uses staged approach (12-month then lifetime); US GAAP uses lifetime losses immediately
options.C: Both use identical lifetime expected loss models
options.D: Neither requires expected loss recognition

questions.explanation: IFRS 9 uses a three-stage approach: Stage 1 (performing) recognizes 12-month expected losses; Stages 2-3 (deteriorated credit) recognize lifetime losses. US GAAP's CECL model requires lifetime expected losses from day one for all financial assets. CECL may result in earlier and larger loss recognition.
questions.tip: Credit losses: IFRS staged (12-month → lifetime). CECL always lifetime from day 1. CECL generally more conservative initially.

questions.question: Under IFRS 2, how are forfeitures handled for equity-settled share-based payments?

options.A: Estimate expected forfeitures upfront (same as US GAAP allows)
options.B: Must account for forfeitures as they occur (no estimation)
options.C: Forfeitures are ignored in the calculation
options.D: IFRS does not address share-based payments

questions.explanation: Under IFRS 2, entities estimate expected forfeitures at grant date and update throughout the vesting period. This is similar to the US GAAP approach under ASC 718, though US GAAP allows a policy choice to either estimate forfeitures or recognize them as they occur. IFRS requires the estimation approach.
questions.tip: Forfeitures: IFRS requires estimation. US GAAP allows policy choice (estimate or as-occur). Both result in similar cumulative expense.

questions.question: Under IFRS 3 and ASC 805, how are subsequent changes in contingent consideration classified as a liability measured?

options.A: IFRS: adjust goodwill; US GAAP: through income
options.B: IFRS: through income; US GAAP: adjust goodwill
options.C: Both: through income
options.D: Both: adjust goodwill

questions.explanation: Under both IFRS 3 and ASC 805, contingent consideration classified as a liability is remeasured at fair value each period with changes recognized in profit or loss. This is a converged treatment. Contingent consideration classified as equity is not remeasured under either framework.
questions.tip: Contingent consideration (liability): Both IFRS and US GAAP remeasure through income. This is a converged area.

questions.question: Under IFRS 10, what are the three elements required for control of an investee?

options.A: Majority ownership, voting rights, legal authority
options.B: Power over investee, exposure to variable returns, ability to use power to affect returns
options.C: Management control, financial control, operational control
options.D: Board representation, veto rights, financial dependency

questions.explanation: IFRS 10 defines control based on three elements: (1) power over the investee, (2) exposure or rights to variable returns, and (3) ability to use power to affect those returns. This is a principles-based approach. US GAAP uses a similar control model but also has specific VIE guidance that can differ in application.
questions.tip: IFRS control: Power + Variable returns + Link between them. Similar concept to US GAAP but IFRS is more principles-based.

questions.question: Under IFRS 11, how is a joint venture accounted for by participants?

options.B: Equity method only
options.C: Choice of proportionate consolidation or equity method
options.D: Full consolidation

questions.explanation: Under IFRS 11, joint ventures (where parties have rights to net assets) must use the equity method. Proportionate consolidation is no longer permitted. Joint operations (rights to specific assets and obligations for specific liabilities) account for their share of assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses directly. US GAAP similarly requires equity method for joint ventures.
questions.tip: Joint ventures: IFRS and US GAAP both require equity method. Proportionate consolidation was eliminated under IFRS 11.

questions.question: How do IFRS and US GAAP treat extraordinary items?

options.B: IFRS prohibits; US GAAP allows
options.C: Both prohibit extraordinary item presentation
options.D: IFRS allows; US GAAP prohibits

questions.explanation: Extraordinary items are prohibited under both frameworks. IFRS has prohibited them under IAS 1 for many years. US GAAP eliminated the extraordinary item classification in 2015 (ASU 2015-01). Unusual or infrequent items may be separately disclosed, but not as 'extraordinary.'
questions.tip: Extraordinary items: Prohibited under both IFRS and US GAAP. Separate disclosure of unusual items is permitted.

questions.question: Under IFRS, a Statement of Changes in Equity is:

options.B: Required as a primary financial statement
options.C: Replaced by the Statement of Retained Earnings
options.D: Combined with the Statement of Comprehensive Income

questions.explanation: IAS 1 requires a Statement of Changes in Equity as one of the primary financial statements, showing all changes in equity including comprehensive income, dividends, and owner transactions. US GAAP allows presentation either as a statement or within notes, making it less prominent than under IFRS.
questions.tip: Statement of Changes in Equity: Required primary statement under IFRS. US GAAP allows statement or notes presentation.

questions.question: Under IFRS, how may interest paid be classified in the statement of cash flows?

options.B: Financing only
options.C: Operating or financing, consistently applied
options.D: Investing only

questions.explanation: IAS 7 allows a choice: interest paid can be classified as operating or financing activity. Once chosen, the policy must be applied consistently. US GAAP requires interest paid to be classified as operating (with limited exceptions). Similarly, IFRS allows dividends paid to be operating or financing, while US GAAP requires financing.
questions.tip: Interest/dividends in cash flows: IFRS allows policy choice. US GAAP is prescriptive (interest paid = operating, dividends paid = financing).

questions.question: Under IAS 23, borrowing costs directly attributable to acquisition of a qualifying asset are:

options.B: Capitalized as part of the asset's cost
options.C: Policy choice to capitalize or expense
options.D: Capitalized only for investment property

questions.explanation: IAS 23 requires capitalization of borrowing costs directly attributable to acquisition, construction, or production of a qualifying asset. This is mandatory, not a policy choice. US GAAP (ASC 835) also requires capitalization of interest for qualifying assets. Both frameworks now converge on this treatment.
questions.tip: Borrowing costs: Both IFRS and US GAAP require capitalization for qualifying assets. This is a converged area.

questions.question: Under IAS 19, how are actuarial gains and losses (remeasurements) on defined benefit plans recognized?

options.A: Amortized through profit or loss using corridor approach
options.B: Immediately recognized in OCI, never recycled to profit or loss
options.C: Immediately recognized in profit or loss
options.D: Choice of corridor, OCI, or immediate P&L recognition

questions.explanation: IAS 19 (2011 revised) requires immediate recognition of remeasurements in OCI. These amounts are never reclassified (recycled) to profit or loss. US GAAP allows the corridor approach (deferring gains/losses beyond 10% of larger of PBO or plan assets) or immediate recognition in OCI. Both end up in equity, but US GAAP amortizes from AOCI.
questions.tip: Pension remeasurements: IFRS = immediate OCI, no recycling. US GAAP = corridor or immediate OCI, with subsequent amortization to P&L.

questions.question: How does IFRS approach uncertain tax positions compared to US GAAP (ASC 740)?

options.A: IFRS has a specific two-step recognition/measurement model like US GAAP
options.B: IFRS uses expected value or most likely amount under IAS 12/IFRIC 23; US GAAP uses a two-step threshold model
options.C: Both use identical approaches
options.D: Neither framework addresses uncertain tax positions

questions.explanation: IFRIC 23 requires measurement using either expected value (probability-weighted) or most likely amount, depending on which better predicts resolution. US GAAP uses a two-step approach: (1) recognition threshold (more-likely-than-not to be sustained), then (2) measurement at largest amount with >50% likelihood. Different approaches can yield different results.
questions.tip: Uncertain tax positions: IFRS uses expected value or most likely amount. US GAAP uses two-step (recognition threshold then largest >50% amount).

questions.question: Under IAS 20, how can a government grant related to the purchase of equipment be presented?

options.B: Only as a reduction of the asset's cost
options.C: Either as deferred income or reduction of asset cost
options.D: Immediately in profit or loss

questions.explanation: IAS 20 allows two presentations for grants related to assets: (1) present as deferred income and recognize systematically over asset's useful life, or (2) deduct from carrying amount of the asset (resulting in lower depreciation). US GAAP does not have comprehensive government grant guidance and often analogizes to other standards.
questions.tip: Government grants for assets: IFRS allows deferred income or reduce asset. Both result in same net income over time.

questions.question: Under IAS 41, how are biological assets (living plants and animals) measured?

options.B: Fair value less costs to sell, with changes in profit or loss
options.C: Lower of cost or net realizable value
options.D: Fair value, with changes in OCI

questions.explanation: IAS 41 requires biological assets (such as livestock, orchards, crops) to be measured at fair value less costs to sell. Changes in fair value are recognized in profit or loss. This differs significantly from US GAAP, which generally uses historical cost for agricultural assets. Bearer plants are now measured under IAS 16 (cost model or revaluation).
questions.tip: Biological assets: IFRS = FV less costs to sell, gains/losses in P&L. US GAAP = generally historical cost. Major difference for agricultural companies.

questions.question: Under both IFRS 5 and ASC 360, how are assets held for sale measured?

options.B: Historical cost only
options.C: Lower of carrying amount and fair value less costs to sell
options.D: Net realizable value

questions.explanation: Both IFRS 5 and ASC 360 require assets held for sale to be measured at the lower of carrying amount and fair value less costs to sell. Depreciation ceases once classified as held for sale. This is a converged area between the two frameworks, though some detailed application guidance differs.
questions.tip: Held for sale: Both frameworks use lower of carrying amount or FV less costs to sell. Converged treatment.

questions.question: How does the IFRS Conceptual Framework treat the concept of prudence (conservatism)?

options.A: Prudence is not mentioned in IFRS
options.B: Prudence is a fundamental qualitative characteristic
options.C: Prudence supports neutrality - caution when making judgments under uncertainty
options.D: Prudence requires understating assets and overstating liabilities

questions.explanation: The revised IFRS Conceptual Framework reintroduced prudence (cautious conservatism) as supporting neutrality. Prudence means exercising caution in making judgments under uncertainty, but not in a way that introduces bias (asymmetric treatment). US GAAP's framework has historically been viewed as more conservatism-oriented, though neutrality is also emphasized.
questions.tip: Prudence: IFRS reintroduced as supporting neutrality (caution without bias). Not asymmetric conservatism.

questions.question: When a company adopts IFRS for the first time, what does IFRS 1 generally require?

options.B: Full retrospective application with certain optional exemptions and mandatory exceptions
options.C: Use US GAAP values without adjustment
options.D: Restate only the current year

questions.explanation: IFRS 1 requires full retrospective application of IFRS in the opening balance sheet and comparative periods. However, it provides optional exemptions (e.g., deemed cost for PPE, business combinations before transition) and mandatory exceptions (e.g., hedge accounting, estimates) to make transition practical. Reconciliations from previous GAAP are required.
questions.tip: IFRS 1 adoption: Retrospective with exemptions and exceptions. Opening balance sheet restated. Reconciliations from previous GAAP required.

questions.question: Under IAS 24, what specific disclosure is required for key management personnel compensation?

options.B: Only total compensation
options.C: Compensation by category (short-term, post-employment, share-based, etc.)
options.D: Only names and titles

questions.explanation: IAS 24 requires disclosure of key management personnel compensation in total and by category: short-term employee benefits, post-employment benefits, other long-term benefits, termination benefits, and share-based payment. US GAAP requires similar related party disclosures but the specific categories differ, and SEC rules add additional requirements for public companies.
questions.tip: Key management compensation: IFRS requires disclosure by category. US GAAP/SEC has similar but somewhat different requirements.

questions.question: Under IFRS 8 and ASC 280, segment reporting is based on:

options.B: Geographic regions only
options.C: Management approach - how management views the business internally
options.D: Product lines only

questions.explanation: Both IFRS 8 and ASC 280 use the management approach: operating segments are identified based on internal reports reviewed by the chief operating decision maker (CODM). This is a converged standard resulting from joint FASB/IASB work. Segments reflect how management organizes the business, not external categories.
questions.tip: Segment reporting: Converged standard. Management approach based on internal reports to CODM.

questions.question: Under IAS 29, when an entity's functional currency is hyperinflationary, what is required?

options.A: Change functional currency to a stable currency
options.B: Restate financial statements in terms of the measuring unit current at balance sheet date
options.C: No special accounting required
options.D: Use historical cost for all items

questions.explanation: IAS 29 requires entities with hyperinflationary functional currencies to restate their financial statements to reflect the measuring unit current at balance sheet date. Non-monetary items are restated using a general price index. There is no equivalent US GAAP standard - hyperinflation is addressed through change to a stable reporting currency in practice.
questions.tip: Hyperinflation: IFRS requires restatement using price index. US GAAP has no equivalent standard (typically changes functional currency).

questions.question: Under IFRS 17, how are insurance contract liabilities generally measured?

options.B: Using building blocks: discounted cash flows, risk adjustment, and contractual service margin
options.C: At fair value through profit or loss
options.D: Using statutory accounting principles

questions.explanation: IFRS 17 uses a building block approach: (1) discounted estimate of future cash flows, (2) explicit risk adjustment for non-financial risk, and (3) contractual service margin representing unearned profit. The CSM is released as services are provided. US GAAP (ASC 944) uses different models including premium deficiency testing.
questions.tip: IFRS 17: Building blocks (cash flows + risk adjustment + CSM). Significantly different from US GAAP insurance accounting.

questions.question: When IFRS does not specifically address an issue, what does IAS 8 require?

options.B: Develop policy using IFRS standards addressing similar issues, Conceptual Framework, then other standard setters' pronouncements
options.C: Leave item unrecorded
options.D: Always seek IASB interpretation

questions.explanation: IAS 8 establishes a hierarchy for developing accounting policies when IFRS doesn't address an issue: (1) apply requirements in IFRS addressing similar matters, (2) use definitions, recognition criteria, and measurement concepts from the Conceptual Framework, (3) consider other standard setters' pronouncements, academic literature, and industry practice. US GAAP has a similar hierarchy in ASC 105.
questions.tip: IFRS hierarchy: Similar IFRS → Conceptual Framework → Other standard setters/literature. Similar to US GAAP's approach.
